comment: As for chicken rice I've been looking for the best. What do I mean when I say best, the softest chicken meat, no weird smells of chicken, the fluffiest rice and awesome sauce (ginger, garlic, chili, etc.). This place has it all.This place is not located in a convenient location mind you, but once you get there the food will sure please you. A train and bus ride is what I took.The chicken was succulent yet soft and very fragrant. Rice was good with the sauce.This trip was well worth it!

Probably the best chicken rice in SG? I think not.What's good? Fresh ginger sauce was spot on. Liver & gizzard was good but far from foie gras. Service was good & friendly. What could be improved? Chili sauce too watery & diluted for my liking. Chicken thigh lacked the gelatinous jelly I like at Tian Tian. Rice was rather plain. Chicken soup was an improvement over dish water but still weak. Overall nott bad but overhyped.

The sign here reads "Probably the Best Chicken Rice in Singapore".It was definitely juicy!  Basically, the chicken and rice are cooked separately in the same flavored broth which results in juicy chicken and fragrant race.  Served on the side is a bowl of the broth.  All of it was delicious.  This their original location and they recently opened another one in the Clementi area.  For a quick, inexpensive and filling lunch, this a wonderful option!

We were brought here by a local that loves it. We probably wouldn't of tried it on our own especially with the other review on Yelp.  I'm very glad he brought us.It's small and intimate the owner was there and actually waited on us, she is wonderful.  The table shared a seafood pasta dish, which we don't eat seafood but others liked. Deep fried meatballs, which everyone liked. Rib-eye to share which was good and then I had the bolognese pasta which was so good, I didn't share that.Also we got the chocolate lava cake and tiramisu for dessert. I would totally go here again without a problem. You need to check this place out. I've travelled to Italy north and south trust me, stop by and say hi to Jen for us.

The ingredients were comically stingy. The 12-inch pepperoni pizza ($17.90 before any additional charges) had an average of 1 pepperoni per slice, so that the pizza looked ridiculously naked.Didn't come with any condiments (e.g. chilli flakes, cheese).

address: 321 Alexandra Rd #02-01, Alexandra Central Singapore 149053 Singapore
comment: Came by just a couple hours ago for lunch to celebrate my boss's birthday. The menu came with poor descriptions and gave us little idea of what we were about to order, and it was difficult to make an informed choice.And the food? It could've been decent if it wasn't served as cold as Lee Kuan Yew's dead body. The calamari was colder and soggier than a dog caught in the rain, and we had to send it back to the kitchen for a hot batch. The calamari, when arrived hot and evidently freshly-made, turned out to be good. Why didn't the kitchen do that in the first place? What was management thinking? It's mind-boggling.

address: 73A Ayer Rajah Crescent #01-27, Timbre Singapore 139957 Singapore
comment: For those of you who've suffered a few of my ranting reviews, you'll know that I am as rabid a fan of every part of the pig as there ever was.  I believe that on balance we should be eating less meat, but that when we do, the whole animal should be enjoyed, all the way down to the knobby calcified bits.  I deeply appreciate anybody who takes the time and extra effort to respect the pig by pouring all their love, knowledge and skill into bringing out the very very best facets of flavor, aroma, and texture from each morsel of porcine anatomy.  I believe such individuals to be on the side of the angels, one of the good guys, menschen, deserving of praise, respect and general adoration.  The fine dudes at Iskina fall squarely into this category of human being.  There is nothing pretentious, overwrought or melodramatic about Iskina's pig.  They understand that they are just facilitating a process rather than creating anything.  They let time, the laws of thermodynamics and the product do its thing and in the end, they know that the end product will be nothing less than the sublimation of all the good things that nature has to offer.  Their role in the whole thing is to let nature take its course and to bring it to you as quickly and freshly as they possibly can.What is it about roast pork fat, that layer of epiphany hiding just under the crisp veneer of corporeal integrity that so drives me crazy every single time?  Maybe it is because the experience defies definition, description, cataloging, or chronicling. I may conceive of words like ethereal, unctuous, decadent, seraphic, and climactic, but in the end they are just words, so much powdery dust in the mouth, when what I experience each time pork fat attains body temperature and melts over the papules of my sensation is nothing short of revelatory.  Iskina's belly-chon or belly lechon does not disappoint.  The skin is goodness and light itself, a brown crispy rind, barely layered over that pale vein of subcutaneous fat, a gossamer thin covering barely concealing the voluptuous pleasures underneath.  This truly took time, skill and the restraint bestowed by expertise, maturity, and doing the same damned thing over and over again.I won't sully this review with mundane details like price point or serving portions.  I'll just say that something this good over steamed rice with some chili vinegar and a sprinkling of ajinomoto laced soy would easily make it onto my list of "One Food I Could Eat Everyday for the Rest of My Life", but alas, I'm back on no-carbs for the time being.  Till I fall off the no-carb wagon, nirvana will just have to exist in my early morning waking dreams.

address: 20 Lengkok Bahru #01-17, Academy Block Singapore Singapore
comment: If you are old like me, you would remember this cafe called "Petals" at Treasury Building. They were run by students in training to be chefs and wait staff in top restaurants. They then had changed their name to "Charcoal". Now they have relocated here and changed their branding to "The Sapling". The concept is the same, most-times tasty food served by eager wait staff who at times made mistakes. But hey, they are in training so cut them some slack lah! I enjoyed their pricing the most! All mains are no more than $12 and you can top up $4.90 for a buffet of soup, salad bar and desserts with your main. My good friend who had dined there a few times did mention that I should manage my expectations as there were hits and misses with their food. She usually eats the same main there and there was once the fish she felt was too overdone, to the point that it was charred. We were a big group of us and we had:Vongole with Linguine - this was a fusion dish which was essentially Hokkien fried mee style with linguine instead of yellow noodle and white clams instead of prawns. It's a tad spicy with worked well as a dish! Good!Tea-smoked Duck with Pasta in cream sauce - I thought the duck slices were very good, could taste the tea-infused flavours. I liked the creamy sauce but another friend who had it didn't. Oh well. Seafood Stew - I didn't quite understand the name because the dish was a big slab of fish with skin that  was pan-fried till crispy and the meat juicy. This was served with white clams cooked in creamy sauce (diff from Smoked duck dish). I cleaned the plate. Roasted Chicken with Rice - this is their Christmas special I think which is a set for 2. Each person would have half a chicken, 2 onion rings and a serving of mushroom flavoured rice. My kids didn't like the rice but I thought they were WONDERFUL!We had the top up so we had mushroom soup which I found a little bland. Nothing a bit of salt didn't fix. I also had some potato salad and some greens with one of the 6 dressings available. I didn't have space to try their 3 desserts available and the fruit cups that they had. I think I would need to plan harder by skipping breakfast the next time I return. Yes, there will definitely be a 'next time'!!!
Their cold noodles are amazing. If you can their rib with bone you are a lucky soul. Otherwise I love their pork jowl and beef short ribs.

Good spot for Korean BBQ- Good variety of high-quality beef - both marinated and non-marinated options are excellent- They also have other non-grill items like pancakes and soups - these are average/okWould recommend as a good spot to meet up friends. A bit pricier than your average Korean BBQ but worth it

The place is less airy and the atmosphere more downbeat compared to the old location. Food also seems less special. Our kimchi tofu soup is not so potent, the pajeon too soggy, and the kalbi gui less oozing with flavours (a bit disappointing since they use good-quality meats). Still, one of the better Korean BBQ joints in Singapore - one of the few using charcoal fires. They also charge higher prices, so it's good but not necessarily good value.

from a Korean, this place sucks. rather have Mcdonalds honestly...  the dude doesn't know how to cook any meat, he nearly burned half of our order, and the soups don't taste like anything. Go waste your time somewhere else smh

Chang Korean Charcoal BBQ on Dempsey Hill was good, but I have to say that going to 8 Korean BBQ last week ruined me. I don't think I'll ever try any other Korean BBQ that tops it. We walked in to Chang and the place was very bright, with a lot of seating. They were steadily busy, but not packed. There were mostly families with their young children. It was definitely a lot quieter than 8 Korean BBQ and our server was very friendly and helpful with our questions. We ordered the beef/pork combination along with red wine and were pleased with our meal. The food was good, and it was easy to follow our Paleo diet. The price at Chang was about the same as the price at 8 Korean BBQ, but I think we got a lot more bang for our buck with the pork package offered at the latter. It included a stew along with all of the meat and sides. Don't get me wrong, the service and food were both good, but nothing about Chang Korean Charcoal BBQ stood out to me that would bring me back. There's a lot of competition out there and I think 8 Korean BBQ has the edge.

My favorite all-around Korean restaurant in Singapore. We've been coming here for 7 years and the staff hasn't changed so it must be well-run. We always get our favorite table and they give consistently friendly service. The food is fresh, wholesome, and traditional Korean fare.

We enjoyed our experience here, there were 9 side dishes which were replenished on demand. We ordered both BBQ -marinated prime rib, marinated chicken and the pork belly as well as two soups (spicy soft tofu and beef rib soup) and stewed beef ribs. Overall the BBQ was excellent - well marinated and cooked perfectly. Agree with earlier poster on the ventilation, first time ever for me to not smell like korean BBQ after a meal!The soups were good but the stewed rib was fairly average. We were comped rice cake soup for New Years at the end. Will try more places but worth a visit.

Now what I can about this place is - average.  Nothing really stood out that will compel me to come back.  The meat was well seasoned and tasted good.  As for the rest of the dishes, got to say tasted better.  Services was attentive perhaps it is a rainy Friday night and we were quite early? All in all, I say Gai at Suntec is far better in taste and value.

Chang Korean BBQ Restaurant is known for their meats, which ironically enough even has a vegetarian menu.You don't have to worry about smelling like BBQ food afterwards as the ventilation is superb. No need to BBQ your own food either as the staff will do that for you.There is a fantastic variety of dishes that you may choose from. But don't get too excited just yet because at times the service can be truly slow and unprofessional. Having eaten there several times, I have received mixed views each time. Sometime the service is get and very accommodative, other times they are slow and it takes several minutes to get the attention of a waiter or waitress. Service aside, the food is delicious, everything is BBQ'd well, you don't have to worry about anything as the staff are well trained and excellent BBQ-ers.

Lunch is simply a prelude to dessert.  This is a great place for a nice lunch for people with sweet teeth for around $20. Why? After ordering a main or sandwich, you can add on dessert of your choice, soup-of-the-day, or a nice coffee for $3 each.  So you can get a nice 3-course meal for $20-$25 (soup/main/dessert), which is a *steal*. The mains range from $15-$25. $15 gets you a lovely open-face sandwich with chips and salad. I like the avocado and salmon sandwich. Then they've got fancy more pricey mains like duck or foie gras -- I haven't tried them yet.You *must* get dessert. We're talking chocolate praline cake, lemon tarts, yummy yummy stuff. They have at least 10 beautiful selections of dessert.Staff is friendly and will make recommendations for dessert, dishes, etc.Free water. This place is near the Proctor & Gamble building.

address: 460 Alexandra Road  #01-15 Alexandra Retail Centre Singapore 119963 Singapore
comment: The authentic Belgian Waffles serve as a perfect desert after you had your lunch at ARC. If you had a salad for lunch and you know you will be hungry around 4PM, bring back some stroopwafels to your desk. These are not that great as in Holland, but way better value than the ones you can buy in Starbucks. The staff is friendly and will let you try before you commit to buying a whole pack. This store is a great addition to ARC, if only it is for the great smells they release into the air when baking one of those delicious waffles. Come to think of it...I might get waffles for breakfast tomorrow. Opening HoursMon-Fri: 8am - 8pm Sat-Sun: 10am - 6pm

address: Blk 109 Bukit Purmei Rd #01-157 Singapore 090108 Singapore
comment: Best curry in Singapore. If ya want great curry and cheap cheap prices. Thanks s is the place. Prata a little on the sweet side but all and all great food for the money.

My favourite lunch place at one north. Fantastic food and service, the restaurant is very spacious and bright. They have plenty healthy options and also amazing traditional Turkish baklava!Their grilled chicken breast is a must try!

Decent Turkish place with good lunch sets. Personal go-to is the rice with grilled chicken - a simple dish but pretty comforting. The rice is buttered / well-seasoned and goes well with the tender chicken. Lunch set also comes with soup and dessert. Lunch set aside, we also like the hummus and baba ghanoush - both above average. Tried the baklava for desserts, which were way too sweet for our taste

Very nice and tranquil restaurant, a stone throw away from Fusionopolis 2. Good authentic turkish food, the mixed kebab is delicious and plentiful (good for two), the hummus is very good too.  Positions are generally on the small side.

My favorite dish here is the patlican salatasi, on the menu it's billed as "Eggplant Salad", which is necessary, I understand to make it easier to identify and order, but BORING!!  I'm a sucker for eggplant, aubergines or brinjals.  The very quality that puts most others off is I think the aubergine's most attractive quality, the viscid, almost mucoid quality of the juice and the flesh when stewed or boiled.  This very quality is exploited fully in dishes such as patlican salatasi and baba ghanoush which adds interesting textural notes and facilitates the amalgamation of acid, oil and heat.  This results in a dish that posseses a depth of flavor in excess of its simplicity. The salatasi is the Turkish version which mashes the eggplants rather than cutting them up as is done for baba ghanoush.I'm glad there's some place I can go and just sit down to a dish of salatasi without having to do it myself and end up with a serviceable but not very good version, and have to clean up after.  Yes, if you haven't yet gathered, I am pretty lazy.This is a very small casual cafe.  In Turkey, it might really be the hole in the wall that it is in Fusionopolis.  Casual, unpretentious and with food that doesn't aspire to more than to please and represent its origins, Arkadas is "good peoples" in my book.

A good casual Turkish place nested on the top floor of Fusionopolis. If my co-workers did not bring me there, I certainly would not have known about it. After all, there are hardly any restaurants at the top floor. Most food joints are on the ground floor. It has no big sign boards or anything. Just sitting humbling at a little corner, waiting to be discovered. Surprisingly there were quite a few people :)  1. Chicken Doner Kebab - Good! The chicken was tender and juicy. I ordered mine without mayo and it tasted great :) My only concern would be that the serving size is too small for men. Price $8.90 (before tax). 2. Houmus with pita bread 3. Aubergine salad with pita bread - Learnt that Aubergine = Eggplant. While I am usually ok with eggplant. This version was super sour! It tasted like a pickle which I hate. Overall, a bit overpriced for the regular office crowd (especially for the their kebab's portion). Expect to spend $20/pax.

Hummus ($7.90 or so?) was recommended by a foodie friend! It was pretty good, not that much oil, rather substantially composed of chickpeas (i.e. pretty thick). The bread was also delicious.. I think it's Turkish bread (raised) rather than pita (flat). Anyway, crisp on the outside and soft (ish) on the inside! Just hot out from the oven :)Eggplant salad ($6.90 or so?) was a bit lacklustre, no char grill :( Sad. I actually liked the coolness of it, and the slight tang though! Went very well with the warm bread :)We also had cream of asparagus soup ($5). It was fine, nothing to shout about. Tasted somewhat like cream of mushroom plus some asparagus thrown in. Tender and well cooked asparagus though!Our friends ordered musakka (minced beef w green peppers n tomatoes, and lots of cheese) and izgara kofte (minced lamb beef patties). They were fairly pleased with the former but not so much the latter. Girl found it a little spicy while guy found it a bit dry. My bf liked the kofte though, finished what they couldn't!Our chicken shish kebab was pretty good, tender. 5 pieces on the skewer. Does NOT come with grilled veggies (or asparagus stalk) like it looks like on the website though.. Ah well. Butter rice was pretty good!Choc mousse ($4) had been highly recommended too, it was very very thick as well. Choc shavings on the top, yum! Baklava ($6 or so?) came as three small squares. It was seriously a sugar overload.. Or perhaps honey overload. Instant diabetes!!! Overly sweet/sugary, unfortunately.

This is one of the top 3, if not the best, restaurant in Fusionopolis. It's a good place to be at when you're bored of your chap chai bing and wanton mee in the food court. Arkadas Café sells authentic Turkish food. There's the hummus and a variety of kebabs. My favourite main course is the salmon cheese which is perfectly baked with a thick layer of cheese sauce with asparagus by the side. The salmon is fresh and you can see the layers of the reddish meat separately as you slice into the fish.They serve free iced water too, always a plus point in my opinion.Check out eatlikeawhale.blogspot.sg for more pictures and reviews.

Decent choice for lunch around the area, though slightly pricey, less authentic with small portions.This cafe caters to the Fusionopolis lunch crowd and is a welcome change from the usual food court offerings in the basement. They have a couple of doner wraps and kebab set meals that are value for money. The bread is fresh, and service is friendly. I particularly recommend the pide (turkish pizza-like dish).The mousakka was okay but a little too tomato-ish and the baklava was disappointing. The filo pastry wasn't crispy and it was extremely soggy. I was looking for a couple more exotic dishes and desserts like lahmacun, imam bayildi and kunefe but they weren't on the menu. A lot of the items were modified to cater to the Singaporean (and asian) palate. The turkish bread (ekmek) is strangely listed as "pita" under the menu for some reason. I don't claim to be Turkish food expert (lived with a couple of Turkish roommates and was educated on how to cook and eat the stuff) but I don't think the place is particularly authentic with the modified sauces and spices.Good to try, but looks like I'm heading to Arab Street.

Great food!  I eat here often, it is definitely one of the best restaurants in the immediate area.  The waitress staff is very slow and needs prompting at all times, this gets annoying, but the delicious food and Raki makes up for it.

They've got a nice lunch deal where you can get a soup and a kebab or a meat wrap. Their bread is hot and fresh. I like their lentil soup, and the service is very polite.My vegetarian friend went with us once though, and he was very disappointed with the vegetarian options. We ordered moussaka, hummos, and he had a vegetarian pizza, but he didn't seem so happy with it.

Very tasty middle eastern food, friendly and efficient service. I have tried the lamb kebab and Adana kebab, both of which were excellent. The lamb kebab in particular used excellent quality ingredients and was grilled just right. Wifey ordered the chicken doner kebab and a side of hummus. Hummus was decent but the doner had fried instead of grilled chicken, which resulted in some disapproving clucks.As other reviewers have pointed out, the prices are high for the quantity of food served. Other than that, no complaints.Once again, service gets two thumbs up.

fantastic turkish/middle-eastern food up in fusionopolis. this place was a gem - expert, wholesome cooking coming out of a tiny kitchen. and it was manned by the most unlikely - and very likable people too - plus, plus.reasonable prices and decent portions too - I think this might be the totally uncool but entirely amiable and completely delightful country cousin of the town-cool hipster joint.it's a tiny cafe on the top floor of the fusionopolis building - but packed out during a weekday lunch. the proprietors and servers are old chinese aunties and uncles who would be seemingly less out of place in a local kopitiams - coffeeshops - they reminded me of my grandparents; upon seeing my camera, the uncle-in-charge very nicely told me in mandarin to take more photos and to post them something nice online. and so I am.there was a more ethnic kitchen staff walking around with food - which I suppose explains the expertise of the kitchen. we started off with warm fluffy pide and hummus; the bread was crusty and delicious, the hummus decent.I had a grilled chicken breast served on a single large asparagus stalk. the chicken had char, and was moist and tender - at a standard I would expect from a restaurant - and the asparagus perfectly al dente. my friends had the adana kebab (a lamb-beef mix) and the baked rice - both of which went down easily enough.we finished with baklava - and while it wasn't the best I've had, it's more than I expected. the pastry was sweet (because this is middle-eastern - I have a persian friend who takes his tea with 5 sachets of sugar) though not tooth-achingly so, and moistened just enough for the filo layers to still be discernible. I remember a slight floury after-texture, but nothing off-putting.a tiny, unpretentious, but immensely likable café - and gratifyingly close to the gastronomic wasteland of my workplace. I see repeat visits in my gastronomic crystal ball.
This is my go to place when I want cheap tasty food. Minced meat noodles with cucumber and a tiny soup is my choice. The lady is super nice and they're open late.

Delicious fresh Teochew cuisine. Really enjoyed the meal with my family on Sunday.Steamed fish was fresh and healthy.Ngor hiang was just rightFlat noodles had wok heyOyster omelette was fluffy Veges were sauteed well.Light, fresh and delicious.

This place has lots of good reviews, so I thought I better come and check it out.The Oyster Omelette was okay - fluffy and reasonably tasty. Most places seem to do a crispy version, which tastes better, but taking this on its own terms it was pretty good.The Hei Zhou (prawn and minced meat roll) was well fried, bouncy and very fresh, with noticeable crunch from the water chestnuts. However it was mostly meat and didn't contain much prawn.The braised tofu was okay - normal. The plain fried kai lan was okay too.The best part of the meal - for better or for worse - was the coconut. The coconut water was sweet and rich, and te flesh was tender, tasty and easy to scoop out.Sadly they were out of orh nee (sweet yam paste) so we couldn't try that.Overall this place is passable, but overrated. The portions are generally a bit small too. Oh, and there's no menu so ordering is like a Mandarin language oral examination (though the prices turned out reasonable).

This is my family regular dinner place. It's VERY fresh. The owners are pleasant and unpretentious. Good and solid. Once they start cooking for your table, the dishes come out really quick. We have tried a few of the teochew restaurants along this stretch but this is our favourite. They do steady business even on Sunday nights when Chinese restaurants are usually quieter after 9pm.It seems to be run by family. Very down to earth.Once I sit down, if I'm feeling like yam paste, I order it first to "chope" it. Otherwise, it's often sold out. In fact I just had it sold out again this past Saturday night when I asked for it halfway through my meal.Regular items we order:1) pomfret steamed teochew style2) hae cho (prawn rolls)3) braised duck and beancurd (or just the beancurd)4) oyster omelet5) kai lan fried with garlicSometimes I order:1) pomfret steamed hong kong style - they do it light, very fresh. I like it! This usually goes for about $50 for a good sized one. Still cheaper than many small restaurants and definitely cheaper than the bigger fancier restaurants.2) crayfish (small is $28. seemed to come with 6 half pieces in a chilli crab style sauce)3) hokkien mee - quite lipsmacking! Good sized portion.4) cold crab - it's fresh of course but I really do enjoy my crab hot so I seldom get this.I'm a coconut fan and they serve them here.Hmm, maybe I should try other things next time. But it's hard when you've got all the regular items always served up so fresh and consistently.

Old school no frills place that serves Teochew cuisine.Good items to order are the oyster omelette, chilli crayfish, steamed fish and hae zhor (shrimp rolls). Prices are higher if you go for the seafood items.Good news, they used to be cash only but now accept VISA! (Testament to rising food prices)The restaurant is family-run, and originally started as a stall in the Zion Road Hawker Centre more than 15 years ago. They have since moved here, and prices have gone up over the years and portion sizes have shrunk, but the food is generally consistent.I've been a long-time customer and I appreciate their no-nonsense approach to Teochew cooking. With the stalwarts in the area slowly disappearing, I really hope they will stick around.

address: Blk 120 Bukit Merah Lane 1 #1-51 Alexandra Village Food Center Singapore 151120 Singapore
comment: Kinda what it says on the tin - yummy soups. Short queue for cheap, nourishing delicious bowls of soup. Cooked for so long the tender pork falls fresh off the bone. A bargain at about $4 each.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: This is my second time eating at the Hard Rock Cafe and it was awesome. The food was amazing and the service was great. The place was packed as usual so I had to wait a while, but it was worth it. It's the perfect place to have lunch or dinner at when visiting Sentosa. The music and the decor are all what you would expect from a Hard Rock Cafe. Their menu has a big variety of food and once ordered your food will arrive in about 15 minutes (at least for my food). Their merchandise shop is also very cool. You can get T-shirts or other souvenirs from the shop to remember your time at HR Cafe. Their T-shirts have really great designs on them and they have them in all sizes.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: Hard Rock Cafe Sentosa is a great dining option about a 3 minute walk away from the entrance to Universal Studios Singapore. Food here as well as most places in the vicinity is fairly expensive. The staff is very friendly and the decor modern & welcoming. No complaints about the food as it was very filling, and it was nice to get out of the Singapore heat to take in a meal here.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: We were staying at Hard Rock Hotel and had a discount for staying. The service is absolutely terrible (though friendly and very nice, it was slow)!!  The food was very good, though, and the drinks are delicious.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: 100% better than the HRC across the street from the Four Floors of Legitimate College Ladies Earning their Tuition.We ate here after a disappointing day in Sentosa (Tourist Trap AHHHH. Totally Waikiki but in Singapore. Stay. Away. Forever.) We try to eat at HRC any place we go and we'd already been to the one we shall not name, and decided to re-do our experience. The personality of the staff wasn't amazing, but they didn't seem to hate their jobs either, and that's nice.Our food was HOT. We got the jumbo platter in which we devoured all of it. It was clearly fresh and super delicious. I probably could have just eaten one of those.I got the satay burger, which was excellent, but I couldn't eat all of it. It was great and I would definitely recommend someone to to the HRC Sentosa if a typical HRC Experience is what they're looking for.I finally got my magnet, and a tee shirt :)

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: Worst bloody mary ever...citron vodka and tons of ice.  Stayed at HR Hotel bar not open til 1pm...in a RESORT???SAVE YOUR MONEY AND TIME!!!

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: I don't often walk away from restaurants feeling annoyed, but tonight I did. I ordered a burger and instead they brought me a salad. I was hungry and didn't want to wait even longer, so I accepted the salad instead.I had to reorder a side of fries they hadn't brought out to me. At the end they tried charging me for the salad which was more expensive, even though I saved them money by not having them cook the burger I ordered. Over all I felt the staff didn't handle their mistake well and weren't apologetic in a

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: I hate complaining but this place kinda sucked entirely. We showed up, 5 of us, place didn't look busy whatsoever but were given an hour wait time. Fine, 40 mins later were offered space at the bar so decided to eat there. Long story short, we would've been better off at McDonald's. The food here was decent but so ridiculously priced. $200 for 5 of us. The bartenders had absolutely no urgency, I had to ask for the check 3 times and was never offered a refill or checked on how the food was, nothing. & lastly, the music totally sucked.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: Great place for lunch. Had the $15 set lunch soup, seabass, bottomless drink and dessert. Great value fresh fish. However the mini burgers are really mini

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: Everything you ever expect from a Hard Rock.  Autographed guitars, videos of Dio playing on the TV's, and a 8 page selection of cocktails. The hostess was nice.  I'm at the bar.  It's not very busy right now.  The beer is cold.  The restaurant is clean.  The prices are high - about S$19 for a basic burger, but in context of the location, it's probably average. This is just an expensive part of the world. I gave it 3 stars because it really is just average.  Nothing exceptional, nothing atrocious. If the guitars weren't on the wall and Dio not on TV, I could just as easily be at a TGI Fridays in Naperville Illinois.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: I've known Hard Rock since I was a kid and always felt it was an overpriced commercial gimmick overplayed, but I'd have to say after looking for a solid place to park my flip flops, allow the kid and wife to refuel while I sample cocktails, this place still has rock n roll left in it.Ribs were monsterous for the price, and the cocktails are not watered down . Generous pours , and good sized glasses. This is a welcome retreat from the heat in Sentosa. Calling this my Sentosa Refuge... singapore sling, chaching!

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: I was with my wife and a friend. Starving and craving a burger, I thought it would be an easy meal at hard rock. My wife is vegetarian and the menu is relatively vege friendly which helped. Friend and I ordered classic burgers (medium and medium rare) while my wife ordered a kale salad. Everything was extremely salty, including the salad, and the burgers were clearly frozen patties that would never be able to achieve medium doneness. I admit we finished the food (as mentioned above, we were starving) Mentioned to the waiter that everything was super salty, even the salad, and he comes back to say that the kitchen says that we ordered a salty salad, which is bizarre to me. I understand the concept of supply and demand, especially on a tourist island, but I'm totally shocked that hard rock can't even get a burger right. Spend your money elsewhere.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: One of those Hard Rock Cafes where you walk out thinking "why did I even go?" Overall we've had 4 different waitresses taking our orders etc. Gotta say neither one of them looked happy working there nor had any Hard Rock spirit. Had my Coke coming out 20 minutes after my partner had hers already. Food was okay but way too overpriced. Next time I'll just visit the Shop!

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: Popped in for a late lunch and got the $15 lunch set menu ... Was really nice, biggest decision was which main to get and the friendly waiter made my mind up for me. I'm not a big fish eater but thought I'd give it a try and it was nice. Bottomless drinks is great, especially if you're thirsty like I was. Soup was pretty average but for $15 what can you expect. Will go again. Set lunch menu is only available during the week from 11am-3pm.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: This is one of the best places we've eaten at in Singapore. The food itself was great and the service was relatively quick considering there was quite a few people there. However it is not cheap, we paid $90 for 2 meals and 2 drinks. The alcohol was also expensive (not sure if it is just I'm used to it being cheap or not). I got the vegetable fajitas. It was a big serving and tasted delicious, I recommend.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: The service is slow. We were :30 seconds away from walking out, just to place drink order. We were passed by tons of servers. Waited over 7 minutes for our check and a coke refill. Pathetic. I do not recommend for anyone.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: Very friendly and helpful service. This cafe is not yet participating the the new Hard Rock Rewards Program. No AAA discount.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: I'm a regular at most Hard Rock Cafe's around the world. This one was a little bit old or at least it felt like it. But you get everything a hard rock has. Okay food, cold beer and great ambience.  My service was pretty decent so that's why I gave it a three star.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-209 to 214 The Forum Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: Going to Hard Rock Cafe almost makes me feel like a tourist, even if it is simply in Sentosa. Hard Rock Cafe has been on Earth for as long as I can remember and I enjoy trying out the Hard Rock Cafes in the different countries I visit. Awhile ago, a friend from school decided to visit me in Singapore and as she was a tourist and I felt like being one, we went to Hard Rock Cafe for dinner. It is not very different in design from other Hard Rock Cafes. It is dark inside with a bar area and loud music. Apparently there is live music on some nights, but there wasn't any the night we went. The food though was very different. Serving sizes are definitely smaller than those overseas, or at least those that I'd been to. We ordered the Hickory smoked Bar-B-Que Combo with ribs, chicken and smoked pulled pork since we couldn't make up our minds. It was beyond disappointing when we took our first bites and the meat was dry. The BBQ ribs were covered with a thick layer of sauce but the flavour had not even begun to enter the meat. I've had much more appetizing smoked pulled pork and the overall look of the dish was all the more unappetizing. The food looked like it had simply been thrown on the crowded plate and the sauces mixed with each other. Perhaps it is because I had expected much more from Hard Rock Cafe that has led to such disappointment. We decided to round off our meal with cocktails. It was the first cocktail my friend has ever had and she said that she probably would not have another one again. Given the rather expensive prices, I probably would not visit this Hard Rock Cafe again especially since I can get better American food elsewhere.

The garden cafe calls itself an eden santuary and it really is so. It is sheltered from the hustle and bustle of the busy roads with the lush greenery surrounding it. Turning in, we were greeted with a colourful mini play area for kids and a naturally lit greenhouse-esque cafe.M has been here previously and was quick to decide on the Teriyaki Chicken Salad ($11). The festive bowl of vegetables greeted us in a bit. Salads are often thought of as a boring, monotonous dish with a lot of crunching involved but Onaka showed that you can get both taste and texture. You also got a slice of bread with butter along with the salad, said butter was nicely warmed up by the afternoon sun (how's that for natural!).Being ravenous, the Omega-3 Salmon Rice Superbowl ($12) was the perfect dish to get. I got a deep bowl of grilled salmon flakes, sweet corn and boiled peas adorned on a bed of brown rice - super hearty, super healthy.Onaka also boosts a range of juices in its "Juice Bar" and the food it serves is (wait for it): dairy-free, egg-free, gluten-free, low GI & GL, sugar-free , vegan and vegetarian. You may not know all the dietary technicalities but you will know when you get good food, which is what Onaka offers. They have a different menu for breakfast & lunch and another for dinner. Already planning another trip down!
Delicious juices, salads, and excellent coffee with non-dairy options. Nice atmosphere outside - a peaceful oasis from the city.

Nice hawker center with adequate selection. Its less overwhelming than the more central centers. As a vegetarian, several places were able to leave out the fish paste to accommodate me. My boy loved the Thai place.

This hawker centre is pretty much middle-of-the-road as far as hawker centres go in Singapore. Its fare is good all around, but nothing stands out. I came for a bite after hitting up Fat Boys across the street, so just had a serving of kai lan and chicken fried rice. I will say that the banana 'shake' (you get it from the stall in the back corner on the right hand side) was quite a nice refresher after sitting around in the heat for quite a while. Prices are obviously great, but what else is new at the hawker centre? If you're in the area, this is a good spot to take a break and grab a bite, but nothing to plan around. Do try and go in between rush hours as the tables do fill up quite fast!

address: 1 Lower Kent Ridge Road #01-13/17, One@Kent Ridge, NUH Medical Centre Singapore 119082 Singapore
comment: Ya Kun is not just an outlet or a joint, but a collective entity, like the Borg, but in a good way...goooood Borg. While it had  considerably more modest  and decidedly traditional and humble beginnings as a hawker stall in a local coffee shop preparing and serving local breakfast fare; runny eggs which you'd slurp clean off a saucer after dousing with dark soy and white pepper, and Balsa light sheets of a toasted local loaf slathered with kaya(sweet coconut jam) inlaid with bright yellow chips of cold butter, it has morphed into an entity that is permanent part of the Singaporean gastronomic consciousness.  Ya Kun is as ubiquitous as the Golden Arches and as recognizable.  But also stop to consider that this is a chain of restaurants or fast food joints that serves food that punctilious food-crazy Singaporeans would consider good and worth their time and coin.  You see, in Singapore fast food is not necessarily bad food or even mediocre food. Expectations are no lower just because you may not have sit down service or table linen, in fact expectations may be higher!Simple, tasty, and inexpensive cuisine is so pervasive in Singaporean culinary culture, that nobody thinks twice about expecting good food from a chain restaurant.  Ya Kun is certainly no exception and has continued to serve up what it does best, traditional comfort food quickly, hygienically and in an environment where diners can relive fond childhood food experiences in air conditioned comfort. Add a touch of business savvy and an effective marketing and franchising strategy and you understand why Ya Kun has become a  Singaporean institution and a pioneer in one of the possible evolutionary paths for Singaporean hawker culture.I adore Ya Kun for serving up food that makes me feel good. It's not just that the food tastes good, the flavors are so true and traditional that it instantly brings back fond childhood memories of mornings in a neighborhood coffee shop tucked behind a shady five foot way, it's cavernous interior redolent of carmelized coffee beans cooling after being roasted with margarine and sugar, and the feel-good miasma of toast hanging thick all about you.  Thank you for the memories, Ya Kun!

address: 1 Lower Kent Ridge Road #01-13/17, One@Kent Ridge, NUH Medical Centre Singapore 119082 Singapore
comment: I was unimpressed by my kaya and eggs here (one of my favourite foods). The toast was slightly cold and the amount of kaya was minimal, normally I like lots of spread with thick slices of butter. The eggs were alright although slightly too stiff for my liking. Best kaya and eggs in my opinion are still served at Changi airport!

address: 460 Alexandra Road Alexandra Retail Center #02-22 Singapore 119963 Singapore
comment: I went to this sushi place twice during my trip to Singapore. I love the conveyor belt concept and the sushi was so much cheaper than what I'm used to in California!My go-to order was7 pieces of salmon sashimi (10 SGD), 4 pieces of swordfish sashimi (6 SGD), 4 pieces of yellowtail sashimi (6 SGD).  For the equivalent of $16, I've already gotten $30 worth of sushi. Round out your meal with some inari, mixed tempura, and green tea ice cream and you've got the perfect meal. Actually the mixed tempura was really great -- it came with three pieces of shrimp, a whole mushroom, eggplant and some other veggies. I also liked the scallop sashimi, though not enough to order it a second time. I got a free California roll through their rewards program. It was tasty but I wouldn't pay for it -- I'd rather order something more interesting. The Tuna Mayo Inari was fine, but I'd rather have plain inari. I wasn't a fan of the gyoza, nor the cereal chicken karaage -- I'd rather have tempura.

address: 460 Alexandra Road Alexandra Retail Center #02-22 Singapore 119963 Singapore
comment: If you are game to wait for a long time (more than 5 mins) for someone to show you your table and another 10 mins to wait for someone to take your order, feel free to drop by. This happened on a sparsely crowded Sunday lunch.

address: 460 Alexandra Road Alexandra Retail Center #02-22 Singapore 119963 Singapore
comment: We had lunch here on Saturday before visiting Labrador Park. The place looks new but the food quality was disappointing. I had a premium menu with grilled salmon, spicy mini octopus and scallop with cheese. The seafood tasted not so fresh and the rice was just decent. More than 25 SGD.

address: 460 Alexandra Road #02-20 ARC - PSA Building Singapore 119963 Singapore
comment: Bistroquet, located on the second floor at Alexandra Retail Centre, tries to be a charming and cozy restaurant which would give people a reason to walk all the way down from labrador park mrt to alexandra retail centre. In reality this cafe just offers cafe style dining experience for casuals lunch meetings. On the menu are items such as wood fired thin crust pizza and tartines and gratinated mussels from the grill. They do have a wide selection of wine, beer and ciders...but also serve smoothies. After 3 they have 1 for 1 pizza's, which actually taste very decent and leave a nice wooden flavor.If this place would just admit it is nothing but an upscale harry's, they would be a lot more succesful in drawing in the after office crowd. Opened daily 12:00 pm - 9:00 pm

Rochester Cafe is an independent cafe that serves excellent coffee (Thai Doi Chaang beans) and surprisingly decent savory food (lasagna, wraps, curry chicken). They also serve waffles and ice cream.The various lattes I've tried are all superior to that giant global chain that's 5 minutes by foot so you should come here instead. I've had the signature Thai iced coffee, the iced banana toffee nut latte, and the iced caffe mocha. They also have fusion flavors such as an iced lemongrass americano.Also, try the Thai green curry chicken wrap.
